name: Letter from Lipsius, Justus to Clusius, Carolus, 1605-02-06

Diplomatic.text: I[ustus] Lipsius Carolo Clusio S[alutem] M[ultam] D[icit]. Vere me amas, mi Clusi, et gaudeo, eo magis quod fidum certumque hunc affectum reperire est in paucis. Factio et partium studium aufert et coniunctos etiam divellit. Non fiat nobis: tu senuisti, ego senesco et gloria amicitiae haec ad sepulchrum nobiscum eat. Equidem promitto et gratam sanctamque tui memoriam, si post te vivo. Aureum Valentiniani accepi et gratias habeo: repono etiam in munusculo litterario, quod recens ab ingenio et stilo meo mitto. Sunt Monita et Exempla Politica, inceptum opus, non perfectum, ita vel valetudo abiicit, vel occupatio distrahit, ut vix ultra sim pangenda. Senecam tamen brevi, ut spero, habetis. Exotica tua libens videbo et in iis te amplectar. Vale, Vir amicissime. Lovanii, VI Idus Febr[uarias] cum evocatus Bruxellam irem M.DC.V. Liber meus adhuc non potuit mitti tabellarii nostri culpa. Proximo fiet et via Antverpiensi. [Address:] Cl[arissi]mo et Doct[issi]mo viro Carolo Clusio. Leidae. Francque [Clusii manu:] 1605. Iusti Lipsii, Lovanii, VI. Id[us] Feb[ruarias] ad meam XI Kal[endas] Feb[ruarias]. Accepi Leydae III. Kal[endas] Martii. Respondi Nonis April[ibus].

annotations.text: Monita et Exempla Politica: Lipsius's new publication, meant as a practical illustration to the Politica (1589) and dedicated to Archduke Albert. It was published in Antwerp by Johannes Moretus in 1605.
non perfectum: The manuscript of two more ‘books’, in the hand of a secretary, is preserved in London, BL.
Aureum Valentiniani: Clusius sent Lipsius a golden coin, probably to acknowledge his gift of the two philosophical works of 1604.
via Antverpiensi: The ‘private’ way, via Moretus and Raphelengius. Their usual messenger was a Catholic Leiden woman, Christina.
evocatus Bruxellam: Lipsius was to receive the honorary title of member of the State Council.

metadata.value: Lipsius's next letter was copied by Clusius at the bottom of this letter.
